markdownRemark.html:
Describing a Moving Average Model

  • A moving average model is linear regression model, where the response variable represents some value indexed by the current time period and the predictor variables represent our mean of the value and some white noise error term
  • The moving-average model should not be confused with the simple moving average, which takes the arithmetic mean of a given set of prices over the past number of days

  • Specifically, we can define a moving average model of order rrr as the following:

    st=μ+ϵt+θ1ϵt−1+θrϵt−rs_{t} = \mu + \epsilon_{t} + \theta_{1}\epsilon_{t-1} + \theta_{r}\epsilon_{t-r}st​=μ+ϵt​+θ1​ϵt−1​+θr​ϵt−r​
    • Where sts_{t}st​ is the unknown true value in our current time period
    • Where μ\muμ is the mean of our values (this is constant for any ttt)
    • Where ϵt\epsilon_{t}ϵt​ is the unknown error of the current predicted value and what we will observe
    • Where ϵt−1\epsilon_{t-1}ϵt−1​ is the error of the previous predicted value and what we observed
    • Where θ1\theta_{1}θ1​ represents the percentage of the error ϵt−1\epsilon_{t-1}ϵt−1​ we should include in our model
    • Where ϵt−r\epsilon_{t-r}ϵt−r​ is the error of the rthr^{th}rth previous predicted value and what we observed
    • Where θr\theta_{r}θr​ represents the percentage of the error ϵt−r\epsilon_{t-r}ϵt−r​ we should include in our model

  • We can estimate sts_{t}st​ by using the following equation:

    st^=μ+θ1ϵt−1+θrϵt−r\hat{s_{t}} = \mu + \theta_{1}\epsilon_{t-1} + \theta_{r}\epsilon_{t-r}st​^​=μ+θ1​ϵt−1​+θr​ϵt−r​
    • Where st^\hat{s_{t}}st​^​ is the predicted value in our current time period

An Example of a Moving Average Model of Order 1

  • Let's say we're predicting the price of salmon each month using a moving average model of only the the previous month's data

  • We can define our model as the following:

    st^=μ+θ1ϵt−1\hat{s_{t}} = \mu + \theta_{1}\epsilon_{t-1}st​^​=μ+θ1​ϵt−1​ where ϵt−1=s^t−1−st−1\text{where } \epsilon_{t-1} = \hat{s}_{t-1} - s_{t-1}where ϵt−1​=s^t−1​−st−1​
    • Where s^t\hat{s}_{t}s^t​ is our current prediction
    • Where s^t−1\hat{s}_{t-1}s^t−1​ is our previous prediction
    • Where μ\muμ is the mean of our values
    • Where ϵt−1\epsilon_{t-1}ϵt−1​ is the difference betweeen our previous prediction and the previous observed value
    • Where θ1\theta_{1}θ1​ represents the percentage of the previous error ϵt−1\epsilon_{t-1}ϵt−1​ we should include in our model
  • The table below shows our observed data and predictions of a few iterations
month ttt st^\hat{s_{t}}st​^​ ϵt\epsilon_{t}ϵt​ sts_{t}st​ μ\muμ θ1\theta_{1}θ1​ θ1ϵt\theta_{1}\epsilon_{t}θ1​ϵt​
Jan 1 10 -2 8 10 0.5 -1
Feb 2 9 1 10 10 0.5 0.5
March 3 10.5 0 10.5 10 0.5 0
April 4 10 2 12 10 0.5 1
May 5 11 1 12 10 0.5 0.5

  • We can interpret the second iteration as the following:

    • Our predicted price of salmon in February s2^\hat{s_{2}}s2​^​ is 999
    • The error of our predicted price of salmon in January ϵ1\epsilon_{1}ϵ1​ is −2-2−2
    • The actual price of salmon in February s2^\hat{s_{2}}s2​^​ is 101010
    • The average price of salmon μ\muμ is 101010
    • The percentage of the previous error we wanted to include θ1\theta_{1}θ1​ is 0.50.50.5

An Example of a Moving Average Model of Order 2

  • Now, let's say we want to use the two previous month's data to predict the price of salmon using a moving average model
  • We can define our model as the following:
st^=μ+θ1ϵt−1+θ2ϵt−2\hat{s_{t}} = \mu + \theta_{1}\epsilon_{t-1} + \theta_{2}\epsilon_{t-2}st​^​=μ+θ1​ϵt−1​+θ2​ϵt−2​
  • The table below shows our observed data and predictions of a few iterations
month ttt st^\hat{s_{t}}st​^​ ϵt\epsilon_{t}ϵt​ sts_{t}st​ μ\muμ θ1\theta_{1}θ1​ θ1ϵt\theta_{1}\epsilon_{t}θ1​ϵt​
Jan 1 10 -2 8 10 0.5 -1
Feb 2 9 1 10 10 0.5 0.5
March 3 9.5 1 10.5 10 0.5 0.5
April 4 11 1 12 10 0.5 0.5
May 5 12 0 12 10 0.5 0

  • We can interpret the third iteration as the following:

    • Our predicted price of salmon in March s3^\hat{s_{3}}s3​^​ is 9.59.59.5
    • The error of our predicted price of salmon in February ϵ2\epsilon_{2}ϵ2​ is 111
    • The error of our predicted price of salmon in January ϵ1\epsilon_{1}ϵ1​ is −2-2−2
    • The actual price of salmon in March s3s_{3}s3​ is 10.510.510.5
    • The average price of salmon μ\muμ is 101010
    • The percentage of the error from February's prediction that we wanted to include θ1\theta_{1}θ1​ is 0.50.50.5
    • The percentage of the error from January's prediction that we wanted to include θ2\theta_{2}θ2​ is 0.50.50.5

Determining the Order Parameter

  • The moving average model is parameterized by an order qqq, which refers to the number of lags to account for in the prediction
  • Similar to an autoregressive model, including every single lag variable (or a very large amount of lag variables) is a typical naive approach to fitting a moving average model
  • This approach typically leads to overfitting
  • Therefore, we are interested in choosing the smallest order qqq for our model that will include only the significant lags
  • This will help us avoid overfitting and build a model that will hold up better over time
  • We can determine which lags are most significant by observing the lags within an autocorrelated function (or acfacfacf) chart
  • Specifically, we want to know what order includes only the lags that are most indirectly or directly correlated with the price of salmon of our current month
  • Essentially, we only want to include the lags in our model whose direct or indirect effects (based on acfacfacf) are high in magnitude according to the acfacfacf chart
